At 14:31 04/08/2005, you wrote:
> > _IS_ it ever correct to count wins in TTT?  e.g. because you cannot win
> > against  a perfect player, the best you can do is draw...
>
>We found that the traditional "perfect player" basically just plays
>defensively and makes 3-in-a-row when he stumbles across it.  But, he
>doesn't fully exploit other weaker players.  And if you evolve only
>against a perfect player, all the net learns is not to lose - which is
>pretty boring.

I don't know what properties a traditional perfect-player has, but I think 
we need to distinguish between a real "perfect" player, and one that merely 
never loses.  Call the latter an "unbeatable" player.  Obviously perfect 
players are a subset of unbeatable ones (and players who always win if 
their opponent makes a mistake, but cannot necessarily draw if their 
opponent does not, form another superset of perfect players).

A true perfect player _will_ always will if they can, but like anybody 
else, when playing another good player will generally only be able to draw.

But you are quite right, a player evolved against other players will 
generate tactics based on what it sees in its opponents while it is 
evolving.  a player evolved against only good opponents may well never 
learn to win...

Whereas at the start of evolution when the opposition is all lousy, 
learning to win a few games might well be the way to make rapid progress...

Hmmm....

But a perfect player, will win if it can...

>Or solution to "against a perfect player, the best you can do is draw"
>is this: we've started doing iterated Tic-Tac-Toe.  If a net plays
>multiple games against the same player, and can identify the opponent,
>it can play aggressively against a weak player and defensively against
>a strong one.  The problem becomes a combination of game strategy and
>opponent modeling.

Not sure how that's useful.  I mean, OK if you were playing a complex game, 
then knowing who your opponent is is a useful shortcut to doing the full 
analysis of their playing.  And in a psychological (necessarily "hidden 
information"?) game obviously it is essential...

But for TTT?  You don't need to know anything about the opponent.  All you 
need to do is look up the current board in that file I posted, and:

1) pick any move labelled "where Q wins",
         or if there isn't one,
2) pick any move labelled "where nobody wins"...

("Q" being whatever side you are on).

By this I don't mean that a net is actually going to work using some sort 
of board look-up, I mean that the patterns of winning and losing are simple 
enough that you never need to consider "how my opponent is playing".  You 
just need to look at the current pattern of pieces...

Not that we've yet seen either "perfect" or "unbeatable" players appearing 
yet (we don't have precise tests for them, but a perfect player would never 
lose to a random player).

         Ian

>- Philip
